questions.text: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is known as ______
questions.solution:
The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law.

Laws in Sensory Physiology

  • Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor.
  • Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.
  • Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.

questions.text: A patient admitted to the ward does not feel a sensation of the heat on touching a hot object. Considering the signal reaches the thalamus, which of the following is not transmitting the signal to an intact postcentral gyrus?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the tertiary neuron does not transmit the signal to the postcentral gyrus.

In the thalamus, secondary sensory neurons synapse onto tertiary sensory neurons, which in turn project to the somatosensory region of the cerebral cortex.

The question tests your knowledge of this pathway. It is said that the signal reaches the thalamus and the postcentral gyrus is intact. Still, the person cannot perceive the sensation, so the pathway is broken between the thalamus and the gyrus, which has to be at the tertiary neuron.

questions.text: Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the______
questions.solution:
Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the spinal cord and medulla oblongata. Most of the ascending pathways and tracts do decussate or cross; however, some remain uncrossed.

Dorsal column pathway crosses in the medulla oblongata.

The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract crosses obliquely in the spinal segments.

questions.text: Conscious proprioception is carried by_____.
questions.solution:
Conscious proprioception is carried by dorsal column. Unconscious proprioception is carried by spinocerebellar tract.

Option B and C: Anterolateral system carries pain, temperature, crude touch.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of fibers in the dorsal column pathway?
questions.solution:
The dorsal column–medial lemniscal system is composed of large, myelinated nerve fibers and thus transmit signals to the brain, at high velocities of 30 to 110 m/sec.

Option B: Dorsal column carries fine touch and anterolateral column carries crude touch

questions.text: A patient comes to you for his annual health checkup. He lost his vision due to an accident a few years ago. He now experiences the world through touch. Which of the following Brodmann’s areas processes this tactile stimulation?
questions.solution:
Processing of tactile stimulation occurs in Brodmann’s area in 3, 1, 2.

The human cerebral cortex is divided into about 50 distinct areas called Brodmann’s areas based on histological structural differences.

Areas 3, 1, 2 which constitute primary somatosensory area I, and areas 5 and 7, which constitute the somatosensory association area process sensory information like tactile stimulation.

questions.text: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is_______
questions.solution:
Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is vertical. 

Parts of the body are represented in order along the postcentral gyrus, with the legs on top and head at the bottom of the gyrus.

A cortical homunculus is a distorted representation of the human body, based on a neurological map of the areas and proportions of the human brain dedicated to processing motor functions, or sensory functions, for different parts of the body. The size of the cortical receiving area for impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part. 

Sensory Homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of sensory input to the somatosensory cortex from different parts of the body.

Motor homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of motor output from primary motor cortex to different parts of the body.

questions.text: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for_____
questions.solution:
Somatosensory area has the largest representation for lips. 

The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body.

Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

questions.text: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere would result in loss of sensation in the left facial area.

Each hemisphere receives somatic sensory information from the opposite side of the body in the postcentral gyrus (somatosensory area).

The lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus receives somatic sensory information from the facial and neck region while the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus received somatic sensory information from the trunk and appendages.

questions.text: Lesion of somatosensory area I affects _______
questions.solution:
Lesion of the somatosensory area I affects the localization of sensations.

Bilateral lesion of the somatosensory area I leads to the following impairment of sensory judgment:

  • Inability to localize different sensations in different parts of the body
  • Inability to judge degrees of pressure against the body
  • Inability to judge the weight of the objects
  • Inability to judge shapes of forms of objects - astereognosis
  • Inability to judge the texture of the materials

Pain and temperature are not affected both in quality and intensity in the lesion of the somatosensory area I. However, they are poorly localised. Pain and temperature localization depends greatly on the topographical map of the body in somatosensory area I to localize the source.`

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side

questions.solution:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Itch is carried by______
questions.solution:
Itch-specific fibers have been demonstrated in the anterolateral spinothalamic tract. They are carried by unmyelinated nerve fiber C. Itching can be produced by repeated local mechanical stimulation of skin, variety of chemical agents including histamine and kinins released in the skin in response to tissue damage

Simple scratching relieves itching because it activates large fast conducting afferents (Aβ) that gate the transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to inhibition of pain by stimulation of similar afferents (Gate control theory).

questions.text: Following are the endogenous opioids except_____
questions.solution:
Endogenous opioids, a group of neuropeptides that includes beta-endorphin, dynorphins, and enkephalins.

Opioids cause both presynaptic and post synaptic inhibition reducing excitatory post-synaptic potential (EPSP). Opioids are released from the descending analgesic pathway and bind with opiate receptors on the afferent pain-fiber terminal. This binding suppresses the release of substance P, blocking further transmission of the pain signal.

questions.text: You are examining a patient for a follow-up of severe pain in his right leg. He tells you that he feels much better now that he is taking acupuncture therapy too. Which of the following is responsible for pain relief in acupuncture?
questions.solution:
Pain relief in acupuncture is by the release of endorphin. 

The acupuncture endorphin hypothesis is the primary mechanism of acupuncture analgesia. According to this hypothesis, Acupuncture is thought to activate afferent neurons leading to spinal cord and midbrain centers that release endogenous opioids implicated in pain relief.

questions.text: Fast pain is carried by_______
questions.solution:
Fast pain is carried by neospinothalamic tract.  

Pain signals take two pathways to the brain:

  • Neospinothalmic tract for fast pain/epicritic pain (Aδ fibres)
  • Paleospinothalamic tract for slow pain/Protopathic pain (C fibres)

questions.text: Soldiers wounded in the heat of battle often feel no pain until the battle is over which is an example of stress-induced analgesia. This is due to______
questions.solution:
Stress induced analgesia is due to cannabinoids. 

The stress-induced analgesia, i.e., reduced pain sensitivity during stressful events might be due to:

  • Release of endogenous cannabinoids such as 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG) and anandamide
  • Release of Norepinephrine from brainstem catecholaminergic neurons in the amygdala. 

The endogenous cannabinoid system is a potential target for use in the treatment of chronic pain.

questions.text: Which of the following does not carry proprioceptive impulses?
questions.solution:
Tectocerebellar tract does not carry proprioceptive impluses. Tectocerebellar tract carry visual and auditory impulses.

Spinocerebellar, olivo cerebellar, cuneo cerebellar tracts carry Proprioceptive impulses. 

Vestibulocerebellar tract carry vestibular impulses.

questions.text: Pain and temperature in the thalamus are controlled by which of the following nuclei?
questions.solution:
Pain and temperature in thalamus are controlled by the ventral posterior lateral nucleus. Pain and temperature is carried by anterolateral spinothalamic tract.

Fibres from anterolateral spinothalamic tract and dorsal column synapse in the ventral posteriorlateral (VPL) nucleus of thalamus.

Option B: The pathway from taste receptors includes synapses in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius in the brainstem and ventral posterior medial nucleus in the thalamus.   

Option C: Anterior nucleus functions as a relay station for the hippocampal impulses. It receives afferents from mammillothalamic tract. It sends efferents to cingulate gyrus. 

Option D: Intralaminar nucleus participates in arousal reaction, it recieves afferents from reticular formation of brain stem.

questions.text: Ventrolateral cordotomy for relief of pain in the right lower limb is being performed on a patient. Which of the following is cut in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in the lateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion.

In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level of C1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4.  

Note: The fibers carrying pain sensation ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract while the fibers carrying crude touch and pressure sensations ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract.

questions.text: Pick the correct statement:

choices.text: Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of dorsal spinothalamic tract
Trigeminal lemniscus carries  pain and temperature sensations from the ipsilateral orofacial region
Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei
Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of vestibular nuclei

questions.solution:
Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei

Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of dorsal column nuclei

Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of anterolateral spinothalamic tract

Trigeminal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensations from the contralateral orofacial region

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.solution:
Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

Fibers of medial lemniscus ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord to the medulla, where they synapse in the gracilus and cuneate nuclei.

The second-order neurons from these nuclei cross the midline and ascend in the medial lemniscus to end in the contralateral ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus and related specific sensory relay nuclei of the thalamus.

questions.text: Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to______

choices.text: Loss of tactile but not 2 point discrimination
Loss of tactile and  2 point discrimination

questions.solution:
Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to Loss of tactile and 2 point discrimination.

Widespread bilateral excision of the somatosensory area I causes loss of the following types of sensory judgment:

  • The person is unable to localize discretely the different sensations in the different parts of the body. However, he or she can localize these sensations crudely, such as to a particular hand. The brain stem, thalamus, or parts of the cerebral cortex can perform some degree of localization.
  • The person is unable to judge critical degrees of pressure/weight/texture.
